results.title: Lakes Entrance Surf Life Saving Club
results.creator_credit: ACMI, David Withers and Kim Montgomery
results.brief_description: Members of the Lakes Entrance Life Saving Club discuss why the club plays such an important role within their lives and their community. Founded in 1956, the Lakes Entrance Surf Life Saving Club in 2013 has over 400 members and patrols the beach from November through to Easter. The Club not only provides a vital service to locals and tourists alike, but is also a fantastic way for the young people of Lake’s Entrance to gain life skills, practical knowledge and build confidence.

results.title: Lakes Entrance Fishing
results.creator_credit: ACMI, David Withers and Kim Montgomery
results.brief_description: A story about a fishing family and the importance of the fishing industry within the town of Lakes Entrance. Arthur Allen and his family have maintained a tradition of lake fishing in East Gippsland for five generations and hope to continue for many years to come. Despite the uncertainty of the industry, Arthur, his son Matthew and the Lakes Entrance Fishermen’s Co-op, strive to keep fishing alive in Lakes Entrance.

results.title: Lake Pedder
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Time Frame Productions, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Anna Grieve and Steve Best
results.brief_description: Using archival footage and interviews, this documentary tells the story of Lake Pedder, an alpine lake isolated in the heart of the wilderness of south-west Tasmania, which was flooded to make way for a massive hydro-electric scheme in the early 1970’s. The campaign to save the lake became the first national environmental battle in Australia’s history and subsequently through this fight to save Lake Pedder the world’s first green party was also born. By the time the Franklin River was under threat the environmental lobby in Tasmania was highly skilled and organised as a result of the Lake Pedder experience. Subsequently, it was able to campaign successfully, not just in Tasmania, but throughout mainland Australia for the Franklin River to be saved. Includes interviews with Bob Brown, Peter Hay, Hilary Edwards and others. Narrated by Peter O’Brien.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Film Australia, Time Frame Productions, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Anna Grieve and Steve Best

results.title: Lake Maracaibo
results.creator_credit: Shell, Unidad Filmica and Boris Woronzow
results.brief_description: For centuries Lake Maracaibo, on the north-western coast of Venezuela, and the surrounding countryside have been the home of fishermen and shepherds. Today with the discovery of oil, swampland and savanna are being converted into industrial sites and residential districts.

results.title: Lake
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Suzanne Baker and Stephen Ramsey
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Little world of Dietmar Fill”.
Dietmar focuses on a small freshwater lake near his home in the Blue Mountains west of Sydney. He explores the life of the lake and expresses his concern for the likely impact of pollution on its ecology. Narrated by Robyn Williams.

results.title: Laila
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Margaret Pettigrew and Diane Beaudry
results.brief_description: Laila Paattinen is a working woman. Tired of low-paying jobs, she completed a five-month course in dry-wall installation. Because she had chosen a non-traditional job for women, she ran into resistance in the marketplace. She finally solved her problems by opening her own dry-wall application business. A useful film for women seeking non-traditional jobs.

results.title: Lahaul and Spiti
results.creator_credit: Films Division, Government of India, Mohan Wadhwani and N.S. Thapa
results.brief_description: The mountains of Lahaul and Spiti are situated in the sparsely populated northern Punjab. Shows the people who live in the scattered towns and villages, their work, domestic life, festival and ceremonial dances. Buddhist monks live high in the mountains coming down on occasions to join with the villagers in religious ceremonies.

results.title: Lagged: the story of a convict
results.creator_credit: NIDA, John Clark and Henrietta Clark
results.brief_description: Tells the story of a boy convicted as a pick- pocket in London in 1792 and transported to Botany Bay for seven years. Consists entirely of graphics from the period using sepia-tint photographs and contemporary ballads and suggests that a convict in Australia was better off than a coal miner in England, at least up to 1836. Historical adviser, A.T. Yarwood. Voices by John Krummel, Norman Hodges, Alan Edwards. Written by John and Henrietta Clark and filmed by George Pashuk.
